verses.text: But in the last days, the mountain of the LORD’s house will be established as the highest of the mountains; it will be lifted up above the hills, and peoples will stream to it.
verses.comment: The phrase 'the last days' is prophetic, indicating the Messianic age and the establishment of God’s reign. The mountain symbolizes God's dwelling and kingdom—fulfilled in Christ and the gathering of all nations to true worship. See Isaiah 2:2 for a parallel prophecy.

verses.text: Many nations will come and say, 'Come, let us go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the house of the God of Jacob. He will teach us His ways so that we may walk in His paths.' For the law will go out from Zion, and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: This verse foretells that people from all nations will seek the one true faith. The law and the word go out from Zion and Jerusalem, showing the importance of the unity of teaching and doctrine, and points forward to the worldwide mission of Christ’s Church. See Luke 24:47 for the extension of the Gospel from Jerusalem.

verses.text: He will judge between many peoples and decide disputes for strong nations far away; they will beat their swords into plows and their spears into pruning knives. Nation will not lift up sword against nation, nor will they learn war anymore.
verses.comment: This promise of peace is fulfilled ultimately in the reconciliation brought by Christ. Spiritual unity replaces war and division. This also anticipates the peace of the Kingdom of God, partially realized in the life of the Church and brought to fullness at Christ’s return.

verses.text: But every man will sit under his own vine and under his own fig tree, and no one will make them afraid, for the mouth of the LORD of armies has spoken.
verses.comment: This image of peace and security echoes Solomon’s reign and looks ahead to the Messiah’s Kingdom, where blessing flows to all and fear is removed by God’s own promise.

verses.text: For all the peoples walk, each in the name of its god, but we will walk in the name of the LORD our God forever and ever.
verses.comment: While others may follow false ways, the true people of God are marked by their continual faithfulness to the LORD. This speaks to the visible unity and faithfulness required from believers, walking in one faith and under one authority.

verses.text: In that day, declares the LORD, I will gather the lame and assemble those who have been driven away, and those whom I have afflicted.
verses.comment: God’s promise to gather the broken is both literal (the return from exile) and spiritual (the inclusion of all, even the outcast, in the new covenant people). Christ fulfilled this by healing the sick and drawing in the marginalized.

verses.text: I will make the lame a remnant, and those who were cast off a strong nation; and the LORD will reign over them on Mount Zion from now on and forever.
verses.comment: The transformation of the weak into a holy nation points to the spiritual gathering and sanctification of believers under the everlasting reign of God—fulfilled in Christ, who reigns on God’s holy hill forever.

verses.text: And you, O tower of the flock, hill of the daughter of Zion, to you it will come; the former dominion will come, kingship for the daughter of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The ‘tower of the flock’ refers symbolically to a place of watch and protection, possibly alluding to Bethlehem, where Christ was born and where royal rule will be restored. Christ, the true King, is shepherd and ruler of the new dominion.

verses.text: Now, why do you cry aloud? Is there no king among you? Has your counselor perished, that pain has seized you like a woman in labor?
verses.comment: The loss of earthly leaders causes anguish, fulfilling God’s warnings about judgment, but ultimately pointing toward the hope for a new, greater King and Counselor to come.

verses.text: Writhe and groan, daughter of Zion, like a woman in labor, for now you shall go out from the city and dwell in the field, and go to Babylon. There you will be rescued; there the LORD will redeem you from the hand of your enemies.
verses.comment: The exile to Babylon is both literal and typological of the rescue through redemption. The ultimate fulfillment is in Christ, who redeems His people from sin and death, leading them from exile into the new Kingdom.

verses.text: Now many nations are assembled against you, saying, 'Let her be defiled, and let our eyes look on Zion.'
verses.comment: Though surrounded by enemies, God’s people are never forsaken. The nations’ plans to dishonor Zion are ultimately frustrated, showing God’s providential protection and preservation of His chosen people.

verses.text: But they do not know the thoughts of the LORD, nor do they understand His plan—that He has gathered them like sheaves to the threshing floor.
verses.comment: God’s sovereign plan triumphs over human schemes. The imagery of the harvest and threshing floor recalls judgment and the gathering of the faithful—a theme that Christ develops in His parables.

verses.text: Rise and thresh, daughter of Zion, for I will make your horn iron and your hooves bronze; you will crush many peoples, and I will devote their gain to the LORD, their wealth to the Lord of all the earth.
verses.comment: God empowers Zion, signifying strength given to God’s people to carry out His victory and purpose. The dedication of the nations' wealth to the LORD foreshadows the universal mission and the gathering of all things to God—a key theme in the ultimate unity and sanctification of the people of God.
